title: Generation of non-human primate CAR Tregs using artificial antigen-presenting cells, simian tropic lentiviral vectors, and antigen-specific restimulation
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Isolation of PBMCs from Cynomolgus macaque whole blood
Timing: 3 h
The isolation of PBMCs from Cynomolgus macaque blood is not as efficient as that of human or even Rhesus macaque. We have found that Percoll gives the best results. The Cynomolgus PBMC layer will contain many more red blood cells than human, so ACK lysis is essential for efficient cell sorting.
Dispense anti-coagulated blood into a 50 mL conical tube and spin at 650 g for 10 min at room temperature with the deceleration and acceleration on lowest speed to avoid disruption of plasma layer atop the RBC/PBMC layer.
Pipette off the clear plasma (upper layer) leaving behind RBC/PBMC enriched layer.
Dilute remaining RBC/PBMC layer with 1 volume of PBS.
Place 15 mL room temperature 60% Percoll solution into a 50 mL conical, making sure to avoid getting Percoll on the sides of the tube.
Slowly, overlay up to 35 mL blood on top of the Percoll solution.
Centrifuge blood for 30 min at 650 g with the deceleration and acceleration on lowest speed.
Pipette off the top layer until ∼2.5 cm above interphase.
Use a pipette to collect the hazy middle layer containing PBMCs and put into a new tube.
Fill up new 50 mL conical tube with PBS.
Wash cells by spinning at 650 g for 10 min with the deceleration and acceleration returned to their highest settings.
Remove supernatant and lyse red blood cells.
Resuspend cell pellet in 1 mL of ACK lysis buffer.
Fill up tube to 50 mL with ACK lysis buffer.
Rock tube gently for 8 min at room temperature.
Spin cells for 10 min at 650 g.

Note: Do not exceed 8 min of lysing time for optimal lymphocyte recovery. If cellular debris is visible following lysis, strain sample through a 70 μm filter into a new 50 mL conical tube before centrifugation.
Resuspend cells in 300 μL of flow cytometry buffer and move to a sterile FACS tube.
Sorting of Tregs from PBMCs
Timing: 5 h
To minimize cell death, we perform a low-pressure sort using a 100 μm nozzle into 5 mL polypropylene tubes containing 1 mL of R10 medium as a cushion. Platelets will outnumber lymphocytes in the sample to be sorted. Use your flow sorter’s FSC threshold to eliminate platelets from the screen. Though many platelets will remain in the Treg population following sorting, we have not seen this impact any downstream applications. Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3] depicts the gating strategy we use to isolate Tregs in Cynomolgus macaque.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2122-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Hierarchical gating strategy for NHP Treg sorting
(A) Trigger pulse width vs. FSC gates on single cells.
(B) SSC vs. FSC gates on lymphocytes.
(C) CD4+ CD8- gating removes both CD4- CD8+ and CD4+ CD8+ cells.
(D) Among CD4+ CD8- cells, gate on the top 1%–2% of CD25+ CD127- cells.
(E) finally, gate on CD45RA+ cells.
Make antibody staining master mix containing titrated amounts of the following antibodies:
CD4-BV421 (OKT4).
CD8α-BV510 (RPA-T8).
CD25-PE/Dazzle 594 (BC96).
CD127-PE (A019D5).
CD45RA-FITC (5H9).
Note: The concentration of antibodies used for flow cytometry throughout this protocol will need to be titered by each individual lab to ensure optimal performance on their flow sorter. We stain up to 100 million cells in 600 μL of flow buffer.
Add antibody staining master mix to cells.
Vortex tubes to mix well.
Put tubes in 4°C refrigerator for 15 min.

Wash cells with 3 mL flow buffer, spin for 10 min at 650 g at room temperature.
Resuspend cells in 500 μL flow buffer.
Filter cells through 35 μM strainer top moved from a polystyrene FACS tube onto a sterile polypropylene FACS tube.
Count cells and adjust to 20 × 106 cells/mL with flow buffer.
Sort Tregs using the following successive gates (Figures 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A–3E):
Trigger Pulse Width vs. FSC-A for single cells.
SSC-A vs. FSC-A to gate on lymphocytes.
CD4+ CD8-.
CD25+ CD127- (take top 1%–2%).
CD4+ vs. CD45RA+.
Expansion and transduction of CAR Tregs
Timing: 3 weeks
The goal of this step is to take stringently sorted Tregs and expand them into clinical sized doses of CAR Tregs. As few as 25k Tregs is sufficient to grow clinical sized doses of CAR Tregs. On each day of (re)stimulation, it is critical that aAPCs make physical contact with the T cells, so err on the side of choosing a plate or flask with a smaller surface area rather than a larger one. Since cells transduced with functional levels of CAR are exclusively re-stimulated by K562.Bw6.86 cells, absolute growth can be minimal between weeks 1–2 despite an increase in the percentage of CAR+ Tregs. This contrasts with antigen non-specific stimulation during week 1, where each cell is stimulated. Microscopy of stimulated Tregs can be seen in Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]. Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5] demonstrates the enrichment of CAR+ cells by antigen specific restimulation of CAR Tregs, while Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6] depicts the expected growth of Tregs along with expected expression of FoxP3, CAR, CTLA-4, and Helios.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2122-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Example growth of NHP CAR Tregs over time
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2122-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Enrichment of CAR+ Tregs during manufacturing

CAR staining at the end of each week of Treg growth demonstrating enrichment of CAR+ cells in the Treg product.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2122-Fig6.jpg
Figure 6. CAR Treg growth and flow phenotype
(A–C) Expected CAR Treg growth (A) and expression of FoxP3, CTLA-4, Helios, and CAR on final CAR Treg product (B and C). Each line in panel A represents a single expansion of Tregs, and each arrow represents the day of restimulation with irradiated K562.Bw6.86 cells. Panels B and C represent data from day 18–21 of expansion.
Spin down sorted Tregs and count cells.
Plate 25k–100k Tregs in 200 μL R10 medium with 100k irradiated K562.F12Q.86 cells and 300 IU/mL IL-2 in 96 well flat bottom plate.
Note: We also expand CD4+ CD25- effector T cells (Teffs) to be used as FoxP3- flow and suppressor assay controls with this same protocol with 100 IU/mL of IL-2 instead of 300 IU/mL.
After 48 h, add ½ vial of Bw6-28z virus dropwise, making sure not to disturb any clumps.
24 h later, move cells to 48 well plate.
Double the volume of R10 and add IL-2 back to 300 IU/mL, assuming consumption. Place cells back in incubator.
On day 5, count cells and adjust to 500k cells/mL with R10.
Add IL-2 to cells at 300 IU/mL, assuming consumption.
On day 7, count cells and take 50k cells for surface staining flow cytometry to assess viral transduction percentage, staining in 100 μL of flow buffer containing titrated amounts of the following:
Fixable Viability Dye eFluor 780.
CD4-BV421 (OKT4).
CD8α-BV510 (RPA-T8).
CD25-PE/Dazzle 594 (BC96).
HLA-B7 Tetramer-PE.
Take remaining cells and adjust to 500k cells/mL with R10 medium.
Add 1 irradiated K562.Bw6.86 cell per Treg and add 300 IU/mL IL-2, assuming consumption.

Note: Any irradiated target antigen+ cells can be used for restimulation. In this example, Bw6+ PBMCs (30 gy. irradiated) is an alternative.
On day 9, double media with R10 containing 600 IU/mL IL-2 and move cells to appropriate plate or flask.
On day 11, count cells and adjust to 500k cells/mL with R10 medium.
Add IL-2 to 300 IU/mL, assuming consumption.
On day 14 / 16 / 18, repeat the steps from days 7/ 9 / 11, but with a 1:2 ratio of aAPCs to Tregs.
When cells reach resting state, usually around 375–400 fL in volume as seen on a Coulter counter during cell counting, freeze up to 50 × 106 Tregs in 1 mL of 90% FBS + 10% DMSO solution.
To assess Treg product by flow cytometry, first wash 500k cells in 3 mL flow buffer and then resuspend cells in 100 μL flow buffer containing titrated amounts of the following:
CD4-BV605 (OKT4).
CD8α-BV510 (RPA-T8).
CD127-PerCP/Cy5.5 (A019D5).
CD25-BV421 (BC96).
Fixable Viability Dye eFluor 780.
Incubate in 4°C refrigerator for 30 min.
Wash cells with 3 mL flow buffer.
Spin down for 5 min at 485 g.
During spin, add 250 μL 4× TrueNuclear Fix Concentrate to 750 μL Fix Diluent to make 1× Fix Solution.
Decant liquid and resuspend cells in 1 mL TrueNuclear Fix Solution.
Vortex cells well and incubate at room temperature for 30 min in the dark.
During incubation, make 6.5 mL 1× Perm Buffer per sample by diluting 1 part 10× Perm Buffer with 9 parts Milli-Q water.
After incubation, add 2 mL 1× Perm Buffer and spin down cells for 5 min at 485 g.
Decant, and add another 2 mL 1× Perm Buffer.
Wash cells again via centrifugation.

During second spin, make intracellular antibody master mix in 100 μL 1× Perm Buffer containing titrated amounts of the following antibodies:
FoxP3-PE/Dazzle 594 (206D).
CTLA-4-BV786 (BNI3).
Helios-PE/Cy7 (22F6).
HLA-B7 Tetramer-PE.
Add antibody master mix to cells.
Vortex cells, and incubate at room temperature for 30 min.
Wash cells with 2 mL 1× Perm Buffer, spin for 5 min at 485 g.
Wash cells again with 3 mL flow buffer, spin for 5 min at 485 g.
Resuspend cells in 200 μL flow buffer for analysis on flow cytometer.
LAP assay
Timing: 2 h
The following protocol allows the researcher to determine the extent of antigen specific activation of the CAR Treg product by measuring cell surface expression of the TGFβ propeptide LAP. While the assay using aAPC targets bearing the antigen of interest is described, this assay has also been successful with plate-bound antigen. Example of expected results can be found in Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]. A graphical representation of the LAP assay is depicted in Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8].
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2122-Fig7.jpg
Figure 7. Example data for LAP assay. Bar graph represents mean ± SEM of three independent experiments.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2122-Fig8.jpg
Figure 8. LAP assay
After 24 h of co-culture between CAR Tregs and K562s, Tregs are stained for expression of LAP to determine antigen specificity of CAR Tregs.
Thaw 1 vial each of Bw6- K562 cells (here K562.HLA-A2 cells are used), Bw6+ K562 cells (here we used K562.HLA-A2.Bw6 cells), and K562.F12Q.86 cells as above.
Resuspend cells at 4 × 106 cells/mL in R10.
Wash CAR Tregs with R10 and resuspend cells at 2 × 106 cells/mL.
Add 50 μL (0.1 × 106 cells) CAR Tregs to each of 4 wells in a 96 well polystyrene round bottom plate and then add one of the following:
50 μL R10 medium (no stimulation).

50 μL parental K562 (0.2 × 106 cells, off target).
50 μL K562.Bw6 cells (on target).
50 μL K562.F12Q.86 (positive control stimulus).
Add 100 μL of R10 containing 600 IU/mL IL-2 to each well.
Incubate cells for 24 h at 37°C/5% CO2.
The following day, put entire contents of each well into a flow cytometry tube containing 3 mL flow buffer.
Spin down cells at 485 g for 5 min.
During spin, resuspend the titrated amounts of the following reagents in 100 μL flow cytometry buffer per sample:
CD4-BV421 (OKT4).
CD8α-BV510 (RPA-T8).
LAP-APC (TW4-6H10).
Fixable Viability Dye eFluor 780.
Add 100 μL of the above master mix to each sample.
Incubate cells for 15 min at 4°C.
Wash tubes with 3 mL flow cytometry buffer, spin down at 485 g for 5 min.
Resuspend cells in 200 μL of 2% PFA and analyze on flow cytometer.
Loading PBMCs with CellTrace Violet (CTV) for use in Treg suppression assay
Timing: 30 min
Batches of PBMCs need to be loaded and frozen for use in Treg suppression assays. As the amount of CTV used can impact proliferation and viability of PBMCs, we have described our method below. The CTV labeled before freezing is well maintained, and doing so in larger batches increases consistency between experiments and saves time.
Obtain PBMCs from NHP blood draw as described in the method “isolation of PBMCs from Cynomolgus macaque whole blood[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec3.1]”.
Remove 1 vial of CTV from freezer.
Allow vial to warm to room temperature before opening.
Pulse spin tube to pool reagent at bottom of tube.
Resuspend in 20 μL anhydrous DMSO to generate 5 mM stock solution.
Wash cells once with PBS and resuspend up to 25 × 106 PBMCs in 1 mL PBS.
Dilute CTV stock 1:100 to 50 μM.

Add 110 μL of 50 μM working stock for every 1 mL of cells in PBS for a final concentration of 5 μM.
Mix well and incubate for 20 min at room temperature.
Note: CellTrace proliferation dyes will undergo hydrolysis in aqueous solutions to become non-cell permeable. Dilute stock with PBS just before labeling cells.
To remove free dye from solution, add 5 volumes of R10 and incubate at room temperature for 5 min.
Spin cells down for 5 min at 485 g and freeze in aliquots of 2.5 × 106 cells/vial in 90% FBS / 10% DMSO.
Treg suppression assay
Timing: 4 days
This assay quantifies the antigen non-specific suppressive activity of CAR Tregs. We suggest dedicating a large quantity of PBMCs that have been labeled with cell proliferation dye and frozen to standardize responders across batches of CAR Tregs. We find that irradiated aAPCs are too strong of a stimulus for Treg suppression assays, so the T cell Activation/Expansion Kit (Miltenyi Biotec) is used instead. See Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1] for an example of the plate setup. Example data are depicted in Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9], and a graphical representation of the suppression assay can be found in Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10].
table:files/protocols_protocol_2122_4.csv
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2122-Fig9.jpg
Figure 9. Example data for Treg suppression assay. Line graph represents mean ± SEM of seven independent experiments.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2122-Fig10.jpg
Figure 10. Treg suppression assay
Measurement of CTV dilution after co-culture between Tregs, CTV labeled PBMCs, and α-CD3/α-CD28 beads to assess Treg suppressor ability.
Wash CAR Tregs and Teffs with R10 medium three times to eliminate residual IL-2.
Resuspend cells in R10 at 750k cells/mL.
Thaw frozen, CTV labeled PBMCs as above.
Wash cells twice with R10 medium and resuspend at 750k cells/mL in R10.

Wash α-CD3/α-CD28 beads generated in the section “loading of T cell stimulation particles with α-CD3 and α-CD28 for Treg suppression assay[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec1.1.3]”.
Add 20 μL of α-CD3/α-CD28 beads to 100 μL of R10 in an Eppendorf tube.
Spin cells in a tabletop centrifuge for 5 min at 300 × g.
Remove media, resuspend beads in 500 μL R10 medium, and count. Adjust beads to 375k beads/mL.
Add 134 μL Tregs (100k cells) to well B2 in a 96 well round bottom polystyrene plate.
Fill up wells B3-B7 with 67 μL fresh R10.
Perform 1:1 serial dilution of Tregs by moving 67 μL of cells from B2 through B7.
Remove the last 67 μL from well B7 so that all wells finish this step containing 67 μL of CAR Tregs.
Add 67 μL of CTV labeled PBMCs (50k cells) to each well B2-B7.
Add 67 μL of beads (25k beads) to each well B2-B7.
Repeat steps 83–88 with Teffs instead of Tregs in wells C2-C7.
Create a row of control wells:
Add 67 μL of PBMCs and 134 μL R10 to well D2 as an unstimulated control.
Add 67 μL of PBMCs, 67 μL beads, and 67 μL R10 to well D3 as an unsuppressed control.
Add 67 μL PBMCs, 67 μL Tregs, and 67 μL R10 to wells D4-D7 to use as a single color CTV compensation control for flow cytometry.
Fill surrounding wells with 200 μL PBS.
Put plate in 37°C/5% CO2 incubator for 4 days.
Stain each well for flow cytometry analysis as described above with titrated amounts of the following reagents in 100 μL flow buffer:
CD4-AF488 (OKT4).
CD8α-BV510 (RPA-T8).
Fixable Viability Dye eFluor 780.

Note: To accurately compensate CTV fluorescence, pool wells D4-D7 and leave unstained. These cells can also be used to set the proper voltage for your flow cytometer.
Use FlowJo’s proliferation platform to determine division index for each tube. This represents the average number of divisions per cell in each sample.
To determine level of suppression, compare division indices of suppressed and unsuppressed using the following formula:
  % suppression  =  (  1 −   D i v i s i o n  i n d e  x  S u p p r e s s e d     D i v i s i o n  i n d e  x  U n s u p p r e s s e d      )  ∗ 100
